comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] I prefer the original name for the locality - "Church Hill". Named because it was the location of St Philip' (Church of England/Anglican) Ist and 2nd locations, St Patrick's (Roman Catholic) and Scot's Churches - Lang park was named after a prominent churchman, not the later Labor Premier as many believe. It's a pity the name has slipped from the City's attention and use. I have added "Church Hill" as a tag!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] There was also a Wesleyan Church a little way north on Princes Street.

Sorry to lower the tone with the pissoir note, but they were an interesting, very necessary, and often overlooked part of the city's history.  There can't be too many period photos of them around.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00] Not lowering the tone at all - there's a loo on the same corner now!

 I'd forgotten about the Wesleyan Chapel.

comment.author: 52555726@N08
comment._content:
When I worked for the Sydney City Council, a pissoir was delivered to their workshop at the corner of William Henry Street & Wattle Street Ultimo. It would have been around about the mid 70's.
It had been damaged, and needed some repairs. Being made of cast iron it needed to be braze welded. 
At that time, not knowing of such a thing as a pissoir existed, I found it quite interesting.
I remember a boilermaker saying that when he used his oxy-acetylene torch on the metal, a very unpleasant smell was produced.
Many years of use, boiling off out of the metal, I suppose.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00] and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/52555726@N08] I took a picture of a pissoir situated in Observatory Park, overlooking Kent Street in 1963 or 1964 (I remember because I borrowed a camera from a colleague at work to take it  - I think he thought me most strange!) at the time I was working in Caltex House at 167 Kent Street. Like most bower birds I can safely say 'it's here somewhere!' When I locate it among my photos (not all are sorted nor scanned!) I'll post it on Filckr. I remember I was very proud of the outcome at the time.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/ants47] - Eew! Sounds to me as if the pissoir you are both talking about is the sole survivor of a bygone era, now doing what nature intended under the Harbour Bridge at the north end of George Street - www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/waterexhibition/images/zoom/p... .

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00]That looks like the one ... a magnificent edifice!

comment.author: 23301292@N07
comment._content: My great great grandfather...  Frank Cortese owned the three crowns hotel before it was knocked down...  I would love to see more photos of this if anybody has any.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23301292@N07] Have you tried search on Picture Australia yet? There's sure to be other photos there. AB

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] You will be interested to hear that with the amalgamation of the (Anglican) parishes of St Philip and Holy Trinity (The Garrison Church) from 1 November the historic name will be continued with the establishment of the 'Anglican Parish of Church Hill' or 'Church Hill Anglican' for short.
